Variation Example: Demi-cock (half-chick) leaves home in order to claim back a borrowed (stolen) object (money). On his way he meets animals (fox, wolf) & a river. He takes them along by swallowing them (carries them under his wings). When claiming the money from his debtor, Demi-cock is im-prisoned with animals who try to kill him. Fox & wolf eat the attacking animals, & when Demi-cock is thrown into a fire, the river extinguishes it. Finally Demi-cock obtains the money by swallowing. At home he is beaten by his owner (king) & expells the money (he is eaten by his owner & crows from his stomach.

An old couple (old man, old woman) have a rooster & a hen. The rooster lays no eggs & is driven away. He mocks the king & is sentenced to be drowned, but instead drinks all the water. He is supposed to be roasted but extinguishes the fire with the water he has drunk. He is locked in the treasury & swal-lows all the money. Back home he defecates the money onto a sheet (for the old man). (The old woman sends her hen to do the same, but the animal only produces dung instead of money.)

A man complains that he is a mere slave of his stomach. God takes away his intestines & the man feels sated without eating. After a while the life becomes boring to the man & he asks God to give him back his hunger. He recovers his stomach.

A childless couple wishes for a child. A boy is born but his mother dies. The little boy is slain by his cruel stepmother who closes the lid of an apple chest on him. She cooks him & serves him to his father who eats him unwittingly. The boy’s stepsister gathers up his bones & puts them under a juniper tree. A bird comes forth & sings about what happened. It brings presents to the father & the sister & drops a millstone to the stepmother, killing her. The boy is resuscitated.

A clever boy refuses to tell his dream (about his future sovereignty) to his father & to the king. He is punished & endures various adventures (imprisonment). A princess nourishes him in prison. War is to be declared on the emperor if he is not able to solve two riddles & a task. The clever boy solves the riddles & the task, tells the answers to the princess, & is freed from prison. So the boy averts war, marries the princess, & finally receives two kingdoms.

A wayfarer meets an old man (four or more [relatives]), is referred to an older one & finally to a third very old one. Or, three very old men are asked to solve a problem. The oldest man, who looks the youngest, explains that a man’s appearance depends on the behavior of his wife.In other variants an Irishman goes to Scandinavia & meets an old man, his father & his grandfather. The Irishman obtains certain objects & food that make him see hidden things. When he eats the meat his vision vanishes.

A woodcutter drops his axe in a river (pool). A supernatural being (merman) exhibits a golden & then a silver axe. The man rejects both because they do not belong to him; he only accepts his own. The two other axes are then given to him as a gift. A greedy imitator, who pretends to be the owner of the golden & the silver axe, does not get either & loses his own.

Classifications: The Rich Man's & the Poors Man's Fortune
Variation Example: One of two brothers (farmers) becomes rich, because his fortune works for him, whereas the other becomes poor. The (personified) fortune of the rich one tells the poor brother that his fortune is lazy (asleep). The poor brother beats it (wakes it up) & learns that he should change his profession. He becomes a successful merchant.

A poor brother leaves home to find better luck in another place, but his personified bad luck (poverty) wants to go with him. On a pretext the man locks up the bad luck in a bottle (bag, chest) or buries (drowns) it (and from then on lives happily). When his rich brother frees the bad luck out of jealousy, it attaches itself to him because it is afraid of the clever poor brother.

A rich & a poor friend make a wager: Does wealth come from hard work or from good luck? In order to test their theories, the rich man gives money to a poor craftsman. The first time the money is stolen by a bird, the second time his wife spends it. The poor man gives the craftsman a piece of lead which a fisher-man uses as weight for his net. He receives from him the first fish he catches & in its body he finds a jewel. This proves that fortune is more powerful. When the poor man recovers his luck, the lost money which was given to him by the rich man is often found in a nest or in a jug.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) When King Amasis learns about the military success of Polycrates he advises him not to provoke the jealousy of the gods. As sign of his humility he should throw away the thing he likes most. Thereupon Polycrates throws his most precious ring into the sea. Some days later a fish is given to him in which the ring is found. (2) Because she is haughty (annoyed at a beggar) a rich woman (landlord, businessman) throws her ring into the sea (river, lake) saying, “As improbable as it is that I will see this ring again, so improbable it is that I will ever become poor”. The ring is returned to her & a short time later she becomes poor.

Classifications: Who Will be her Future Husband?
Variation Example: On New Year’s Eve (Christmas Eve) a young woman foresees her future husband, a soldier. When the apparition leaves, she manages to keep his sabre (sword). When the soldier comes home, they marry. Later he finds his sword in a chest. He (nearly) kills his wife (and himself) with the sword because he had suffered so much from the loss of his weapon.
This misc. type includes various tales dealing with a luckless man who becomes successful in all his undertakings when he marries a lucky woman & profits from her luck.
The children of a luckless family find a luck-bringing animal (dog). The (old) father (grandfather) orders it to be killed (destroyed), but the children eat its meat & become fortunate.

Classifications: The Brother about to Hang Himself Finds a Treasure
Variation Example: A rich greedy man, asked for help by his poor brother, gives him instead of money a rope & advises him to hang himself. The poor brother chooses a tree under which the rich man has buried money. When he tries to hang himself, the tree snaps at ground level & he discovers the treasure. The rich brother, having lost his treasure, hangs himself.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with money (treasure) that always returns to its owner or brings bad luck to anyone who steals it.

A miser finds money (treasure), but a voice tells him that it is predestined for someone else. The miser hides it in a hollow tree & throws it into the sea (loses it in a flood). A fisherman finds the treasure & gives it to a smith (a smith finds it when working). The former owner pays a visit to the finder & tells his story. The finder gives him three pastries (caskets), one filled with earth, one with bones & one with the treasure. The miser chooses the wrong one. Thereupon the new owner tries to repay the miser & gives him a cake with the money inside. The miser pays for other goods with it & finally, after other events, the money reaches the predestined owner again.

God (and St. Peter) rewards the hospitable farm -er & punishes the inhospitable one In some versions (mostly Hungarian & Czech) a poor woman of-fers soup to Christ & St. Peter. They reward the woman because they appreciate the specks of fat as “stars” in the soup. When the neighbor woman asks Christ & St. Peter to eat her soup, it is covered with fat & the woman is not rewarded at all.
One of them answers an old man (God) in a friendly manner & is rewarded. The other gives a discourteous answer & is punished.

Christ & St. Peter (God, other supernatural being) visit the mortals . A poor farmer who receives them hospitably is granted three good wishes; a rich man, who refused hospitality, receives three evil wishes. The generous poor person uses his three wishes wisely; the selfish rich man makes two foolish wishes (his horse’s neck broken, his wife stuck to the saddle) & must use the third to undo them. (The same with one wish: to keep doing all day what you begin; one gets good linen all day, while the other throws water on a pig.) Or, a husband given three wishes transfers one to his wife who wastes it on a trifle. In his anger he wishes the desired article in her body & must use the third wish to get it out.

After Christ & St. Peter (pious beggar) have been refused hospitality in a house where a wedding is taking place, they are received hospitably in a poor man’s house. The farmer kills his only cow (sheep) for them, whereupon it comes to life again (many new cows appear).
A man is kind to a beggar (God), but his wife is unkind. The beggar invites the man to him & shows him (among other things) that the woman has been turned into a cow.

God (magician) grants each of three brothers a wish. They choose (1) plenty of wine, (2) sheep, (3) a good wife. Later, when God (magician) comes as a beggar he is refused hospitality by the two elder brothers & he takes their wine & sheep away. The youngest brother & his wife are rewarded for their hospitality.

This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with the journey of the Holy Family to Egypt. The events are usually miraculous: (1) Helping trees/persons: Trees (weeping willow, poplar, alder, fig, palm), plants (fern, broom, thornbush, thistle, hazelnut, rose), fruits (date, pine cone, lupine seed), birds (quail, lark, nightingale, partridge, swal low, wag-tail, pipit, bullfinch), other animals (donkey, sheep, goats, wolves), people (smith, mason, farmer, blind man, Gypsy), & various things (river, well, stream, hoofprints) help the Holy Family on their flight by sheltering them from the sun or from a storm, or by hiding them from pursuers. The helpers are blessed for their assistance. (2) In the corn-legend a farmer tricks the men (soldiers) who pursue the Holy Family by telling them that the fugitives passed by when a field of grain, which is now ripe, was sown. The pursuers give up, not knowing that the grain grew & ripened in a single day. (3) Mary washes Jesus’s diapers & hangs them on a bush to dry. Their healing power causes the dried-out bush to turn green or to bloom, or imparts fragrance to its flowers. (4) Having no where else to bathe Jesus, Mary washes him in certain natural springs, which then & ever after produce warm water. (5) Jesus soothes wolves, which aid the family in their flight. (6) A spider spins its web over a cave in which the Holy Family is hiding. Thinking that no one could have entered the cave recently, the pursuers do not look inside for them (7) Animals (beetle) or plants betray the Holy Family on the way to Egypt & are cursed. (8) Gypsies refuse to give the Holy Family refuge, & for this they are condemned to wander ever after.
One act of hospitality (to two monks) outweighs a life of sin.

A king has built a church, but will not allow anyone to donate money for it. When the church is ready, he erects a sign saying that he alone built it. The next day, his name has been replaced by that of a poor widow. He learns that the widow had donated hay for the donkeys (oxen) used to help build the church. The king regrets his mistake & recompenses the woman.

Jesus & the Apostles are shown hospitality by a woodsman (card player). He is granted a wish & asks that he may always win at cards & be received in paradise. He lives & dies peacefully. On his way to heaven he stops at the house of a wicked, dying notary (enters hell) & wins the notary’s soul from the devil in a card game. St. Peter does not wish to admit the notary, but the woodsman recalls his hospitality & obtains the notary’s ad-mis sion.In some variants he wins twelve games of cards with the devil & is able to take twelve souls out of hell with him. Finally they are all admitted into paradise.

Two soldiers lose their genitals. One of them becomes a servant. The farmer for whom he works gives him a stallion & sends him away because he would be useless as a son-in-law. The soldier shares his bread with a fairy (helps an old woman) who gives him a wish. He wishes for genitals like those of his horse, & marries the farmer’s daughter. He tells the other soldier what happened & advises him to get a horse & to give bread to a fairy. This man also wishes for genitals like those of his horse – but he had not noticed that this horse was a mare.

Classifications: Wishing the Cat to be a Prince
Variation Example: An old woman is given three wishes by a fairy (fish). She wants to be young, to have her house become a palace, & to have her cat turn into a young man. All the wishes are fulfilled. However, she realizes too late that she had had her cat neutered.

Classifications: The Farmwife is Changed into a Woodpecker
Variation Example: Christ & St. Peter ask for hospitality from a farmwife (baker’s daughter). She tries to use only a very small piece of pastry to make her bread (to prepare only a very small loaf), but her bread (pastry) magically grows larger. Neverthe less she does not give them anything (gives them only a morsel). As punishment, she is transformed into a woodpecker.

Classifications: A Man Invites God to his House
Variation Example: A man (woman) makes grand prep a rations for a visit from God, but drives away a beggar who has come to his door (sets the dogs on him). The beggar was God him self. (The man is punished).

Classifications: The Farmwife Must Take Two Snakes as Foster-Children
Variation Example: A greedy farmwife gives only a small piece of bread (nothing) to a beg-gar (Christ), even though her bread magically grows larger. As punishment she has to breast-feed two snakes.

Classifications: The Old Man with the Live Coals
Variation Example: A poor man looks for a light for his fire. An old man gives him embers. When he takes them home they turn to gold. A wealthy man (envious neighbor) purposely extinguishes his fire & asks the old man to give him some coals. He says, “Your house is full of fire”. He finds his homestead in flames.
A man who miraculously became prosperous drives away an old beggar. The beggar was God himself his benefactor. The man is punished & loses everything.
St. Peter Blesses Hospital Thieves.

This misc. type includes various narratives dealing with a man (woman, animal, object) on the moon. Examples: A man (watercarriers, a woman with a butter churn, a man with a bucket of tar) is sent to (can be seen on) the moon for punishment. The punishment is usually for breaking a religious com-mandment (being hard-hearted, stealing, working on Sunday, etc.) In some variants, the figure of a rabbit, a frog, a toad, or a tree is seen on the moon.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A knight who had plundered the property of St. Clement is attacked at night in his bedroom by an army of mice. Unable to ward them off, he prays to be hung in a chest from the ceiling. The mice go away. When the chest is taken down, the knight is found inside gnawed to death by other mice. Or, the Polish King Popiel flees from mice to a wooden tower on an island. Even there the mice find him & kill him. (2) A prominent cleric (Archbishop Hatto I or II) levies taxes dur-ing a famine & demands that those who do not pay (the poor) be burn ed to death. As they die, he likens their cries to the sound of squealing rats (mice). God punishes him for this cruel deed by plaguing him with mice. In order to get rid of the mice, the bishop flees to a tower on a rock in the Rhine (near Bingen). The mice attack him even there & eat him up.

This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with bread (that has not been shared during a famine) that is turned to stone (and/or gives forth blood). Examples: (1) A poor woman asks her sister for bread for her children. The sister hides her bread & refuses, saying, “If I had any bread, I would rather wish it would turn to stone”. Immediately, her bread turns into stone. (When her husband latertries to cut the bread she had hidden, blood flows from it.) (2) A lay brother (baker) hides his bread instead of giving any to the poor. It turns to stone, & is hung on the church door as a warning.

Classifications: Christ & St. Peter in the Barn
Variation Example: Christ & St. Peter spend the night in a farmer’s barn . As payment for lodging the farmer wants them to thresh. They separate the grain by means of fire. When the farmer tries to do the same, he burns the grain & the barn.
God charges a pious man (St. Peter) with the task of managing the weather. The man sends rain, sun & heat to earth but he forgets the wind. Thereupon God deprives him of his responsibility.
